Sound- Its basically classical band choir music or something like that you get the wood winds, brass and some drums all the categories are split into the euphoniums, trumphets, drums, flutes i mean it has everything that would fit with the type of band that the students are in and i must say not alot of music to be 100% honest i thought the music scenes and or practice scenes would be majority of the anime but it wasnt but in the mean time the classical music was great to hear even if you dislike that type of music like myself but i appreciated it sounded great and also the op is one of the best ops in the spring anime season just a really catchy song.


Character- Some of the better characters ive seen in the entire anime season no matter the genre the main character if the anime kumiko honestly wasnt the star in my opinon that spot belongs to reina kousaka and the two of them go on to inspire and help eachother as well as build a friendship after their rocky ending in the past and also make for some beautifully done scenes throughout the anime and some of the most funny moments in the anime. You get a salty b**** excuse me for that but you get her just a bunch of randoms in the band and the characters who are minor but dont really add to the story but overall kumikos friends and her bandmates help her and just give a really good vibe. 

(The two characters i mentioned were just the two i found best there are more characters that actually add to the story)


Enjoyment- 9/10


overall- im giving this an 8/10 personally would give it like an 8.3/10 but rounding it so 8/10 it is or something along those lines it was a really good anime in my opinion one of the best looking anime of the spring season and very enjoyable after not hearing any hype or anything special about it until i actually watched it suprised me and was suprisingly really good.

[b]Disclaimer: This is only my second review on this website so it may not be the best but here's my opinion!
P.S I'll try to keep i spoiler free as possible![/b]
When I first heard about Hibike! Euphonium, I was not entirely excited. I've heard of how K-On wasn't much of a sight to behold (perhaps bias opinion) so when I heard this anime was going to be released, well my thoughts were that of...eh.
What I got in the end was a surprise however. I was taken on a journey, one might say. Whilst having little knowledge about classical musical, I found I could quite easily understandthis anime. However, lets move on.


[b]Story:[/b] 9


I felt the story in this anime was well-developed in the 13 episodes we were given. It was realistic whilst being well-paced; It didn't drag on, as you might say. The information in my opinion was not dumped on us, as many anime do. It was clear, concise and easy to understand especially if you are like myself and lack knowledge of the classical music genre. The story was well-rounded and gave us realistic perspectives from characters that didn't seem forced (however, I'll talk about characters later.) Overall, I rate the story a 9 due to the short amount of episodes and whilst I did say it was well-paced, I believe if it was longer, maybe 24 episodes, we may have seen more development in terms of the characters improving etc.


[b]Art:[/b] 9


The art in this anime was quite outstanding. I don't have much more to say. The scenery was lovely; I especially love the scenes where it featured the shrines. They were gorgeous. It was bright and colourful, however in situations it still kept its colour whilst setting the tone. The only downfall I had was with character design. While I did like the characters looks, they were fresh and bold, I felt they were slightly unoriginal (but that'd be due to same companies working on it.) Overall, I rate the art 9 because the scenery was beautiful but the character designs to me seemed a bit lacking.


[b]Sound:[/b] 10


An anime about music? You'd expect the sound to be good right? Well in this anime I felt it was indeed. From the classical music they were playing to the background tone, I felt as a viewer I was enticed by pleasant melodies we'd often hear. The instruments themselves seemed very clear and crisp, allowing, me again as a viewer, to feel like I was watching something more realistic. The sound helped me feel 'more in-depth' with the anime, giving the scenes nice ambiance. Overall I gave the sound a 10 due to my absolute love for it. I can't say much else.


[b]Character:[/b] 10


I have to say the characters in this exceeded my expectations. I was expecting it to be just 4 or 5 girls playing music and then winning a competition,  however it was not. It showed characters such as the protagonist, Kumiko Oumae, , and her growing passion and love for the instrument she played. The characters to me, seemed, within the given time-frame, well-rounded, developed characters with their own sense of personality I have not seen in many other characters. Among them,  Reina Kousaka had to have been my favourite as (possible spoiler) she was originally seen as being cold, however developed into a character with genuine feelings. Overall I gave the characters a solid 10 due to their development, personality and the way they interacted with each other. (Reina and Kumiko pls :P)


[b]Enjoyment & Overall:[/b] Both 9s


My enjoyment of this anime was quite high. I watched all 13 episodes in one sitting xD I'd say it was a sweet anime, that was pleasantly surprising. My overall score is 9 due to just 9 being the majority score :P 


I'd say in the end this anime was well worth the watch, even if you're not interested in music. It's a short, pleasant anime (that needs a second season) that will please many viewers. 


Hibiki! Euphonium: 9

This is the anime exceeded beyond any of my expectations with its psychological elements and tension which is present throughout the series, especially in the later episodes when it becomes incredibly immersive.
Hibike! Euphonium can be divided into two parts, first one which is from beginning of the series to around sixth episode and the second part consisted of all the episodes onward.
First part of the series serves a purpose of introducing characters and their traits. Story is progressing rather slowly but this part is inevitable not only because it gives us the additional backstory and character development but because the impact of second part wouldn'tbe nearly as effective as it is with it.\n
Second part introduces us to the challenges each and every character has to overcome in their own unique way. At the end of the series we see them overcoming their flaws and reaching to their goal. The tension continues to build up as it makes viewers feel as if they are overcoming those obstacles themselves.\n\n
This story is mostly presented from the perspective of protagonist Oumae Kumiko which is responsible for some of the best psychological scenes in this show. She fights her way through hard times and continues to give her all even after failing many times. The way she expresses her built up rage when she's feeling unsatisfied with herself is incredibly relatable.\n\n
Hibike! Euphonium is a gem among slice of life series. The only reason why I couldn't give this show 10 was because of it's slow start and it being drastically different from the second part of anime, aside from that there are no other complains.\n
I recommend this anime to everyone who is looking for an immersive slice of life with many characters to explore and analyze.

Waiting for a 3rd season of K-ON! was pointless, so instead KyoAni gave us another music anime. K-ON! tells the story of 5 girls in a rock band, but Hibike! is about the people in an high school orchestra.
Story: 8
The plot, if only there was much more to it. Why end it at episode 13? It could have gone much further and I would have rated the story part higher if they could. A bit of the story is about the protag named Kumiko Oumae, trying to change herself in high school as a freshman. The wind brass club she wanted to avoid cannot beavoided because she was dragged by her new friends. She had experience with the euphonium, but she doesn't want to because it caused trouble for her old friend, Kousaka Reina. With this as a beginning, the flow went well and then it got quite cut off short because of it containing only 13 episodes. Still, it made out as a good slice of life and music anime, not losing to K-ON! (Sorry for the comparison to K-ON!, I just had to).


Art: 10

Yes, we know Kyoto Animation are very good with its animation, but with this one, damn it was serious eyegasm. The scenery, the fingering when holding the instruments, its just too damn good. I ain't much of a visual art person, but the animation was outstanding.


Sound: 9

I know my classical music. I don't know much about classical music played by orchestra, but the sound was good too. Especially when Reina had her turn to perform the trumpet solo, the sound just resonates my ears. It was really pleasant, and you can differentiate on how they played in the beginning compared at the end, because it shows the improvements they had.


Character: 9

What made me like Hibike! the most was its characters. Yes there were lots of mob characters, but the main 4 (Kumiko, Hazuki, Midori, Reina) they all had so much to them. I just love Reina although she can be depicted as someone mysterious. She's not a kuudere, she actually shows her emotions. Like the deep bond between Kumiko and Reina, that thing's glorious. I don't like yuri but every time their faces are so close to each other I feel like they have to kiss. The character development is serious. Kumiko and Reina became close after trying their best to be in the orchestra under the tutelage of Taki-sensei, the cute demon. Hazuki who had a thing for Shuuichi (Kumiko's childhood friend) was one of the things I liked and I saw it to the end. When Kumiko kept repeating "I want to improve." that was the most shocking part in my opinion. The change in her to have motivation and in the anime the CV was really accurate, with the emotions being able to conveyed to us audience. I could do much more on characters, but it will end up as spoilers so I leave it to the rest.


Enjoyment: 9

It's a must. It is a must to watch this beautiful anime.


Overall: 9

KyoAni did something amazing, and something of a masterpiece if only the anime had gone longer.

A lot of people say this anime was like K-on. I didn't think it was at all apart from moeness and music. I was kind of expecting a K-on type of thing but right from the first episode I knew it was going to be different. Maybe the manga is more like it, however I haven't read it. In my opinion, the music genre for this was rather unique because I haven't seen an anime where they mainly focus on a classical type of genre, which really made it stand out. And that was another thing why I was exited to watch this anime, tosee how they would take that type of thing on. 


The characters were really delightful and the type you would want to see more of. At one point, I begin to not like a certain character but then grow to really enjoy watching them in this anime. This was mainly focused towards Kousaka Reina, who I didn't really like at first but then realised she's actually a pretty sweet person who was ready to go for her dream. The character of Oumae Kumiko was not what I expected. I was expecting much more of a cheerful energetic type of character, like Yui Hirasawa from K-on. But she turned out to be a kind of cool laid back character which I was glad about :)


The main thing I liked about this anime was the art style. It just made me go wow, the instruments were absolutely beautiful and so were the character designs. I especially loved the characters eyes, they really did stand out. Overall, I think this anime was a nice unique type of work that can really open up to a lot of people, especially if you were ever in a high school band.

Everyone loves a good queer bait. Jk no one does but if you hate yourself a little this show is 100% worth your time. The animation is superb and the soundtrack is damn near flawless in my opinion. I also really enjoyed the characters. Despite the fact that this is ANOTHER highschool anime, it sets itself apart with endearing relationships and a surprisingly heartwarming story. I mean could I give a shit about highschool band? Apparently yes, yes I can. It's not particularly new territory, as far as plot goes. Teens banding together (get it?) to overcome the odds and learn to work together asa team to achieve their goals? Groundbreaking stuff. But seriously it didn't take me long to become emotionally invested. I thought the pacing was good and I never really felt bored.


Now as far as that queer bait goes? Still so damn beautiful. Seriously. I cried twice watching two of Kumiko and Reina's romantic ass scenes. Both of which literally could not be portrayed as anything but homo as hell. I mean if they were intended on being straight, why bother giving them scenes in which they seem to be IN love with each other? To be dicks, that's why. 


You will spend a good portion of time wondering why the cute girls aren't kissing in this anime, but the other 20% of the time you will probably really enjoy it. I mean I haven't bothered watching the 2nd season because I'm still salty af but this was 13 episodes worth of time that I don't want back.

I don't know why out of all the many anime Kyoto Animation had to offer, I had to leave this one off till now. Here's the easy way to sum up my thoughts about Sound Euphonium: I LOVE IT! I LOVE IT! I LOVE IT SO MUCH!!!
Let's start off with straight up the best thing about this anime: The Visuals. Are you serious? This anime is so incredibly beautiful from the art style, the character designs and of course, the brilliant animation by the one and only Kyoto Animation. I'm gonna have to say it. This is hands down the most beautifully animated anime Ihave ever seen. It easily just tops Nagi No Asukara it's so good. I will have to admit that it was kind of hard to guess this was by Kyoto Animation at first but after watching it a while, it becomes very obvious. What gives it away are the character designs. They still retain very distinct similarities to many of what I like to call K-on character designs but they are made to be more detailed and refined. On top of that, you know the animation can't go wrong with Kyoto Animation. Again, it retains many similarities to the moe blob characteristics pioneered by the studio. And the overall backgrounds and all that sort of stuff are just beautiful to look at. If you don't believe me, just watch EP8 and I dare you to tell me otherwise.


Now of course, Sound Euphonium is more than just a visual spectacle. Great attention is also given to the characters. With a band of about 50 or so characters, as much effort as possible is given to many of the side characters instead of just solely focusing on the main ones. And of course, not everyone gets a detailed focus and great amount of screen time. But it is such a relief that the anime at least addresses these characters. 


If we were to look at the more focused characters, this is where it gets real interesting. Kumiko is the main character and it is so amazing to see her development throughout the course of the anime. From when she first started the band in highschool to the end, we see her drastic change in attitude towards music. It was definitely as inspiring as it can get. And on top of that, let's talk about the relationship between Kumiko and Reina. This was one of the most unique and adorable relationships I have ever seen in anime. Their chemistry is unbelievably great that (I know it sounds so weird) they could literally be a couple. It was definitely a highlight of the anime. Even some of the other characters like Sapphire I mean... Midori, Hazuki, Kaori, Haruka & even the Senpai-crazy Yuko turned out to be very interesting important characters just because the anime took the time to flesh out these characters. 


The story of the anime is pretty straight forward though. It is basically a competition-driven anime with the band aiming to reach the nationals. It's a simple premise but this anime does not mess around. I can confidently say that this anime has no such thing as filler. It focuses so intently on the aspects of the band and how the members face trials and tribulations in order to improve themselves, to overcome conflict and to achieve their goal. That is what I wanted to see in so many others of such anime and this one delivered exceptionally well. And even during times when practice is over, it is backed up by interesting conversations between the characters and it can get funny every now and then in order to balance out the seriousness that goes on.


And if all that wasn't enough, we have the main theme of this anime: The Music. This anime has the advantage because music plays a big part in it. And it is during times like these that the soundtrack actually matters to me. If the music is done nicely, it can have an effective emotional impact on the audience. As for the theme songs, while I can easily say they are not the best things I've heard, they are both nice to listen to. This is especially true for the opening theme which after multiple times, it does start to hit me with emotions. That might probably be the result of the show itself though.


Well of course, this anime isn't perfect. There are some teeny weeny problems I find here and there. I did find that the anime does try to rush certain scenes especially during the beginning where it wouldn't be weird to say that some clips lasted for only 5 frames or so. In this first season, we hardly get to know a lot about Asuka. I know that there is some interesting backstory behind this character and I wish to know more about it. And also, it was a really unsatisfying way that the anime ended. There definitely was more that needed to be covered. And that is exactly where the second season comes into play.


I want to see the 2nd season so badly. I love this anime so much. I cannot stop thinking about it. But of course, I'm just gonna leave this series aside for now because there are others to be watched. And I have faith in Kyoto Animation with their reputable track record that they can actually use this 2nd season to the fullest. If they do it right, I know it is a bit too early to say this, but this anime could potentially end up in my Top 10. I will be anxiously praying that it actually happens. But until then, if you have not watched this, I DEFINITELY HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT.

There are very few anime focusing on music. Among them, 80% is about idols and 19% is about small bands (usually rock bands). Then there is the final 1%, that is "Hibike! Euphonium", which is about an orchestra trying to make it into the Nationals.
Made in KyoAni, this unique anime is not only beautiful, it also has a realistic touch to it: believable characters with natural behaviour and dramatic (but not over-the-top) stories.
I was pleasantly surprised, although the first season ends quite abruptly, leaving me unsatisfied.
STORY
We follow a whole orchestra that trains in order to become competitive. Their goal: being selected for the Nationals. Theanime makes it clear that this goal will be hard to reach, and all the characters struggle to level up to the top, which makes the series tense. They also have to deal with their natural feelings and their relationships with the rest of the group.

For the rest, not much events actually happen. Count only 2 competitive events in this first season. Of course it is normal, but it's still few...

The rest of the events are not useless as it deepens the characters a bit, but I do feel like it's lacking something. Maybe the second season will make up to that.



ART

This anime is a candy in the eyes... except when it tries to use 3D. The end of the opening is a perfect example of how not to use 3D, as it feels totally off and distorted.

Fortunately they don't use that much 3D in the episodes, so it's still a minor sitback.


Then, personally I have an issue with the colored highlights in the eyes. It is kind of moe, but as this anime is not actual moe stuff, it just feels off.



SOUND

The music itself is very good, and it uses a classical style that fits the theme. Sadly... the OST doesn't always fit the scenes. I remember one particular scene which is supposed to be sad and dramatic, but a joyful sound plays that just breaks the drama...

So objectively, the music is good, but sometimes it doesn't fit the scenes. To me, that's the most important point of an OST, and they definitely failed that sometimes. It's still nice to hear though.



CHARACTER

The orchestra counts over 60 characters. Of course most of them aren't very deep, even those who have some screentime.

But they did manage to make the group believable. It definitely feels like following the life of such a big group, and seeing their organization was really inspiring.


As for the MC, she's unique just like this anime. She's one of the most believable characters I've seen in a long time, especially because of her struggling with her complicated feelings.



ENJOYMENT

"Hibike! Euphonium" is unique, and that alone made me enjoy it. The visuals are great most of the time, which is yet another good point. But the best part to me was how believable it felt. The characters are realistic, the events are realistic.


I did feel like they shouldn't have tried to add 3D because it was not only bad, it was also unnecessary.

Also, even though the music is great, I wish it would fit the mood a bit better, as it actually destroyed the impact of some scenes.

Now I just wish the second season will offer more, because in the end, I did feel like not much happened in this season 1.

[This review contains very minor spoilers.]
[This is a review of both seasons, together.]
I am glad that I watched this.
I would definitely recommend this to others.
I have watched this once, subtitled. I have only watched the anime.
I will watch this again.
---- Positives ----
The art is extremely good [when it wants to be].
Many scenes have superb art. The characters look amazing, and their emotions come across in their facial expressions and body language. The close-ups are handled extremely well. The series successfully, infrequently changes to a comedic art style to express certain character emotions. The instruments look accurate and the reflections coming off of the brass instrumentslook great. The instruments seem to have their appropriate weights taken into consideration with regard to how their players handle them. The blinding lights on the stage are just how blinding stage lights can actually be.


The solos sound great.

When a single instrumentalist is playing, it's easier for me to focus on how they sound. Whenever there was a single person playing their instrument, it sounded great - not necessarily needing to be highly-skilled performances, but just needing to feel real. Certain solo performances in the series were imperfect on purpose, so those also get credit. I still have that one great trumpet solo stuck in my head.


It gives a good representation of what concert band is like.

There's a focus on how daily practices are managed, with the students sometimes breaking off into sectionals instead of always practicing together as the entire band. Details like that made the environment they were in feel genuine. Also of note, the way the students conduct themselves while waiting in the wings [literally, not the phrase] seemed particularly realistic, and various parts of being at a competition, like waiting to go onstage, were shown, which was nice.


It gives a good representation of what high school concert band is like, while staying uplifting in the end.

There's a focus on the political side of being in high school concert band, such as seniority dictating who gets the better parts. This isn't just another detail of the environment though - it gets a decent amount of focus in the series as something to consider, since the concert band set a high bar for themselves and they can't afford to sit back and settle on the usual ways of doing things. Throughout the series, there is also a focus on how players can sometimes just not care about being competitive and how it changes the mood of the entire band. I won't mention more here, but there are more ways that the story does a good job portraying high school concert band life.


Characters have good, meaningful ties that change during the series.

We learn about individual characters in the series in a deep way through Oumae. The character interactions aren't just limited to her, though, which is what makes this positive stand out. Also, beyond the person-to-person level, we learn about the previous third-years and how they had a profound effect on the current members. We learn something about every attitude and remark throughout the series in an interesting way. Even though I disliked a few characters initially, as I learned more about them, I ended up liking and understanding all the characters by the end of the series.


The soundtrack is great.

I only took note of the soundtrack during important moments in the series, but all those times had fitting songs that enhanced those moments.


The band performances were great [though maybe not for the reason you'd expect].

In my experience, concert band compositions are dull and predictable. The compositions in this series did not disappoint [and that's actually a good thing]. Unlike Shigatsu wa Kimi no Uso [which seemed to focus on entertaining compositions being better than technically challenging ones], Hibike! Euphonium's competition performances focus on the actual way those events are judged - by how challenging the chosen piece is and by how well the band performs the chosen piece, down to an almost nitpicky level. Your band can go play the most fun, bubbly song ever, but the judges will have no qualms about giving your band low marks if the piece wasn't challenging and/or the band's execution was poor. The result is mildly interesting compositions that have challenging sections that the band hopes to play excellently in order to earn gold in the competition, and those were the types of pieces in Hibike! Euphonium.


The voice acting is good all around.

The voice acting is fitting for every character in the series. As a slight oddity, Oumae was voiced extremely uniquely, but I feel that her character animations never quite matched her voice.


The characters pleasantly understand boundaries and work well to progress.

When characters don't understand boundaries, it's nice, but the series can never be emotionally deep. When characters over-respect boundaries [which happens a lot in series], you get spineless characters who juggle the entire series around miscommunications or lack of communications that never or poorly get resolved. The characters in Hibike! Euphonium understand boundaries and don't want to unnecessarily make a misstep ... they are just hesitant enough that we understand their problem and where all involved parties are coming from, but they eventually resolve their issues in good, wholesome ways that make me think that their past hesitant behavior was justified.


The series ends amazingly well.

Without saying more, I think that the series, overall [both seasons] ends particularly well. It's bold and handled very well, on multiple levels that all get a focus in the final episodes.


---- Negatives ----


The art is mediocre [when it doesn't want to be excellent].

First of all, yes, when models are farther from the camera, they rightfully get downgraded artwork. This is fine. But because the excellent scenes just look so outstandingly good, and because there doesn't seem to be a definite cut-off point between the excellent art and the mediocre art, it degrades the experience of watching the series. Usually, the cut-off points for downgrading art happen by distance, total time in the scene, and/or importance of the characters/objects being drawn. Unfortunately, in Hibike! Euphonium, it seems that scenes involving main characters from the waist up can receive varying levels of quality and detail. There's no cut-off point because there are some mediocre close scenes and then there are some excellent scenes that are farther away.

Opportunity for cancel: No, but the art in excellent scenes was just so great that I'm going to irresponsibly state that the art overall is still amazing and this negative can be ignored if you spend enough effort while watching the series.


It seems like there are infrequent 3D scenes [the bad sort of 3D present in this age].

I really want to say that some of the whole-band scenes and podium-and-chairs-on-stage scenes used 3D models [as a negative]. I can't picture Kyoto Animation doing this though, so I assume that those scenes were just bizarrely drawn and bizarrely animated for some reason. What makes a scene appear to be 3D for me: when far-away minor characters suddenly get way more animation frames than normal | when animation frames seem to be a robotic, non-human interpolation | when mostly solid, sometimes unnatural colors are used | when [lighting] shade looks too sharp and/or too-frequently updated | when people/objects have extremely thin drawn outlines | when people/objects look too perfect, accurate between frames, and/or symmetrical. In particular, scenes from the conductors point of view or farther back or higher up seemed to have this style, which led me to believe it was 3D animation.

Opportunity for cancel: Yes, because, although I wasn't counting, I feel that there were less than ten such scenes over the entirety of both seasons, and I'm just sensitive to 3D usage in anime series.

While concert bands are very popular in reality, you do not normally spot them in the medium of anime. However Kyoto Animation's Hibike! Euphonium proves that this concept can be very well worked in an anime series. I found Hibike Euphonium to be a fun treat for all those who play in a band whether it be at a school, a concert hall, or just having fun with your friends. 
  The main personal allure of Hibike Euphonium was that I myself am currently in band class at my school. I've been learning how to play trombone and I guess that was abig reason I had a significant enjoyment of Hibike! Euphonium. Well enough of my rambling, on with the review.


 Hibike! Euphonium, also known as Sound! Euphonium is a anime series based off the light novel of the same name. It follows a high school student who swore off music after middle school and how she meets the Kitauji high school concert band. She rejoins the concert band and them and the rest of the band with old and new friends now are trying to make it to nationals with help from a new band advisor. 


  So, let's get into the meat of what this series has to offer. The art and animation are absolutely stunning. The attention to detail when animating the actual instruments is very evident and the color and lighting were amazingly executed. I must also say that the background music is very good and all of the orchestral instruments melded together well. One complaint with the sound is that to me some of the voice actors sounded a bit annoyingly high pitched. I wouldn't really mind this with a couple of characters but this was a bit too much for my taste. I also must add that they got most of the instrument sounds down and the variety of instruments in the actual concert band is very large.


  Story is a bit 50-50 in terms of quality and intrigue. The concept is pretty good because you don't usually see many anime with high school concert bands as the basis of a narrative. But I felt some aspects of this anime were a tad cliche such as setting. Another negative thing would be the pacing which I felt was off. The plot progression wasn't really that good though it wasn't as bad as in Rokka no Yuusha's case. But I did feel there were some episodes that did little for the plot. The drama and comedy were very good though at certain moments I felt the drama was a little forced though most of the time it was well executed. We do also get some insight on the past of the concert band and how they have had many ups and downs. 


  Characters are pretty good in this anime. There are some cliches present but the characters do have a good deal of fleshing out and they get built from these cliches into something so much more interesting. The character interactions were very dynamic and well executed especially with Kousaka and Kumiko. It is hinted to them being involved in a relationship and I respect that there is a homosexual relationship in this anime but it isn't executed poorly but executed very well. However I would like more relationship development in the second season which was announced. There were also some other great character interaction here which I hope are further developed in the second season. In general I also enjoyed how they highlighted the reality of a concert band. It also details how far people can go and how much people want to improve and get better. 


  I honestly out of all the characters present, found Taki-sensei to be the most interesting. He kind of brought the rest of the characters to life with their development and it seems that he truly knew what to do to bring the band to nationals. Other than him and the main trio, I found the rest of the characters to be good, but not great. I think some more character development would be very good for this anime. 


  So at the end what else is there to say? Hibike! Euphonium is very fun and treat for those who know about band. It can function as a learning experience for musicians and non-musicians alike. The narrative and characters are pretty solid, the animation is beautiful, and the music is awesome. So overall you should check this one out for a unique school life anime because I knew whenever I watched an episode, I wanted to just start playing my trombone.

This is a musician's review.
"Motivation means everything for a human. Once you get motivated you can reach the limits of yourself, the personal sky you own though you dont know yet.
You can get grabbed from the joy of improvement and the tears of your efforts.
Winning or losing is the last thing you need to care about. Cause the happiness and pleasure of discovering your personal sky is an extraordinary and unique experience which can only be born in a journey. The destination is the goal. It matters. But in the end its you and yourself."
This is an anime that teaches this. An anime made tomotivate not only the people who love music but everyone who love something. Something that mean everything for each person's soul.

This is an anime that offers all these feelings in a year (2015) when, even the amount of good anime series that got aired, only two managed this. And this is the one.


I will now speak for each part and justifie my scores.


Story : -8-

Amusing story, with a beginning that fill the audience with the necessary feelings as the plot is about to unfold.

My -8- would be a -9- if every single episode could enfill you with need to watch the next. But this didnt happen as i wached the series in 3 days.

Its still a freaking nice story.


Art: -9-

There isn't much to tell about the art.

Music is wonderfull, colors are attractive, and we are in a new anime age especially after 2014 so...


Sound: -9-

Great opening, gread ending and perfect ost's. Its an anime about music anyways. The anime also achieves to present to the audience the world of some instruments like euphonium, trumpet, tuba and trombone that many would never figure out how difficult and beautiful can be.


Character: -10-

They act like they are in a band. They act exactly how someone would react if was part of real band. Cooperation among the band, tensions between the members, high goals and the dream of getting better and better. Spontaneity and pure love, uncoditional aid, pure friendships and real support. And of course motivation. Some data for the characters of this anime. Definetely a -10- .


Enjoyment: -9-

I never got bored, experienced funny moments, sad moments, moments i felt like i was part of this anime (as i also play music) and the most important thing. I loved my trumpet even more :D


Overall : -8-

A nice review is providing objectivity.

And this one im sure it does. Cause i may bombed you with good comments, but i understand that im a music lover and i may got a bit more excited that some others may do.


Never forget that the things that will change your life are little and are always next to you. The only thing that you have to do is to find these things and then find the person or the emotion that will motivate you to cultivate your love for them.


Have fun watching Hibike! Euphonium ^_^

as being a band geek as myself, I LOVED THIS ANIME. It was a fresh approach on something different, other than your basic school drama cliche, it stands out as focusing on concert band, which people overlook. There may be some flaws, but none of those are a deal breaker. Hibike! Euphonium is a great anime for anyone who loves not just music, but a fresh approach on a grand surface.
Story:
The story is simplistic, yet holds a lot more than meets the eye. There re so many key aspects to it. From the relationship of Kumiko and Reina, a connection of all the band membersas one, The band council, and so much more! And I believe that it unfolds perfectly, even though if I didn't agree much on one decision, but that doesn't break the deal. I also like how realistic band drama is, like how people get jealous, pressure, and the occasional break in the case. The story is well done.


Art:

Hibike! Euphonium has some really great art pieces! The background design is absolutely gorgeous, the animation is great, which compliments the art, and OH MY GOD DO THE INSTRUMENTS LOOK ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. The design and the realistic shine from the brass is very pretty and was one of the key aspects of the show. Even the woodwinds had that occasional shine! The art, truly stands out from many other animes!


Sound:

From this being an anime around music, It still has that slice of life feeling, which in no way is bad. The background score has that simple charm to add into the mood, and is fairly quiet yet simplistic. And you don't necessarily want a loud and obnoxious feeling! However, the concert band songs, ARE GREAT! Especially the two songs they used for the competition, they gave me chills the whole entire time! So the soundtrack, is fairly great!


Character:

The characters of Hibike! are very quirky and lovable. What I thought was really cool about this anime was that the background characters still uphold a lot of detail, yet the main characters stand out by many things by wearing different socks, hair tie, etc. and that is what makes me so happy, because band is for uniting and they do! Kumiko and her shyness to Reina is very cute and makes me giggle at some points but ASUKA IS AMAZING. She is perfect as being the vice president and section leader, yet still makes you laugh and be slightly aroused. She truly is the comedic act of the show and it shines! I love her role as for thee others and can't wait to see more!


Enjoyment:

If you don't like slice of life, you probably won't enjoy it as much as I did, but if you are very musical, you will love it! As for me,  I really enjoyed it! This made me so happy about how realistic, and fun it was to watch! I loved everything about this show and I never wanted it to end!


Overall, Hibike! Euphonium reaches a new pinnacle of music oriented anime and has given people like me the outstanding lift of something new and original. I am very looking forward to season two and hope to see more original animes like this come out fondly soon.

In a word: Band
As a band nerd (and someone who plays Euph), I must say that I started this anime almost exclusively because of the title. I didn't have any expectations going in, since I had not watched any KyoAni stuff before watching Hibike! Euphonium.
Story: 9/10
Overall Plot:
In a word: Realistic
The plot of Hibike! Euphonium is rather down-to-earth, in my opinion. In the beginning, the band members and their director, Taki, set a goal to make it to the national competition. At the beginning, the band seems hopeless. They don't practice, they can't play together, their intonation is all over the place, etc. Taki refuses toensemble the band until they all can play better and take it more seriously. As the series goes on and the characters grow, so does the band. In the end, they compete at the regional competition.


Subplot:

In a word: Tasteful

There is just the right amount of subplot in this anime to add depth, yet not overpower the main plot. Friendships strengthen, past conflict within the band gets uncovered, and Kumiko tries to come to terms with her past. For anyone who was told this is Yuri/Shoujo-Ai and hasn't watched this, I invite you to make that distinction yourself. I'm of the opinion that it is not, since that particular romantic subplot is just that, a subplot. It's not the main focus, and, in my opinion, is not all that important to the story. That's not to say I don't ship it. I do, but I don't think there's enough focus to put it in the Yuri/Shoujo-Ai category.


Art: 10/10

In a word: Detailed

Focus blur, lighting, camera angles, flare, and so much detail was put into making this anime beautiful. I love the art style and really appreciate the time it must have taken to make Hibike! Euphonium stand out, art-wise. I think everything I'd like to say has already been said, so I'm not going to bother with this one that much.


Sound: 10/10

In a word: Euphonious

(Euphonious means having a beautiful sound) The sound is beautiful. Period.


Characters: 9/10

In a word: Deep

I'd like to talk about two characters in particular: Kumiko and Taki.

Kumiko: A euphonium player who said something stupid to Reina in middle school. The memory haunts her, and she wants to quit band going in to high school. She doesn't quit due to Hazuki and Midori urging her to join, and she ends up coming face to face with Reina. She has to come to terms with the incident in middle school, and that drives the subplot for the first bit.

Taki: As a high school band member, I can draw quite a few parallels between Taki and my band director. For starters, both set a goal and an expectation that we will attempt to reach that goal. While Taki has the students "choose" the goal, and my band director creates our goal, I think the goal-oriented nature of both directors is apparent. The expectations set by both Taki and my director drive the work ethic of the students, and in the Hibike!'s case, the plot.


Enjoyment: 10/10

In a word: Biased

I'm a band nerd, I play euphonium, I'm biased. I saw a lot of things I related to because I'm in band. I saw a lot of things I liked because I'm in band.

But

Just because that bias exists doesn't mean you won't enjoy it if you aren't in band. It's engaging and it has some really good writing, art, sound, and characters. It feels real and makes for a great watch.


Overall: 9.6/10

In a word: Recommended

I highly recommend this to anyone who is in or has been in band, anyone looking for a slice-of-life that is in the middle between light and dramatic, and anyone who wants to try slice-of-life.

I'm very familiar with KyoAni's work, we all are. They have their own distinct animation style that we've all seen in every anime they've put out. Their smooth, undeniable pace that drives their anime to its full potential. Even managing to stay true to its adaptation. 
Coming into this, I knew it was a hit from the moment I started. Even going as far as watching the PV & CM several times before digging my way into this show. The feel of this instrumental and character-driven show was soothing, to say the least. There were some moments that left me uneasy, as some conflicts betweencharacters arise during the long-run.

But it still managed to make me feel human, as this is by far the most 'slice of life' anime you'll ever get.


Well done in every category, KyoAni.


And so, the next piece begins (for KyoAni).

This is my first review for an anime so let me shortly introduce myself before it starts: Well I'm a simple person, with simple pleasures, so I'm not as critical as others. I watch anime just for the enjoyment of watching anime. That's all. Simple, right?
So let's begin. I'm not good at expressing myself, but if you are asking yourself, to watch or no to no watch this series, this may help.
Hibike! Euphonium is great series, one of the best that I've seen in this season. Music is a theme for which I am fascinated, so this anime came like no other. 
I really enjoywatching the series 9/10, for everything:

The art was incredible in each episode, I really like the drawing style for both characters to landscapes, completely awesome.

I think the story could be better, but I'm not complaining, it's kinda slice-of-life anime, so I know what to expect. Unlike other slice-of-life, it is going at a nice pace, not too fast, not too slow, and always there is something in the screen that makes you wanna watch.

In summary, Hibike! Euphonium is a great series to watch, it has a bit of everything for all tastes. You would enjoy it, trust me.


Extra: It's a spin-off of PMMM! (May contain a minor spoiler)

Hahaha, well, not really, but do you ever notice the similarities of the characters, I mean, attitude and appearance are similar to each other.


-Reina Kousaka = Akemi Homura

Both distant and cold, but with a great heart. Also black hair and purple eyes.


-Oumae Kumiko = Kaname Madoka

Innocent and always trying to be friends with anyone. Even she felt useless once.


-Katou Hazuki = Miki Sayaka

Our "genki" girl, always smiling and never let anything get her down, except... their chrush.


-Nakagawa Natsuki = Sakura Kyouko

Veteran in the group, and she seems too often to have a carefree attitude, but we all know that's not entirely true. Is a person in who you can trust.


-Ogasawara Haruka = Mami Tomoe

Third year student both, a reliable senpai, but at some point she have to leave. Twintails!


-Kawashima Saphire (Midori) = Nagisa Momoe

Cute and sweet, but don't let she fool you. she knows exactly what's she doing.

I was pretty involved in a concert band during my time in high school, so I could relate to a lot of what was going on in this show from personal experience. I found that a lot of the drama was pretty realistic to what happens in real bands, so I was a little bored watching things that I've pretty much seen before. 
Though personally I felt that the season was pretty boring, there were some moments that were absolutely beautiful which made it worth checking out I guess.
Story 5/10
Like I said, most of the drama in Euphonium is pretty realistic, so I had alreadyexperienced those kind of moments before. Especially the merciless verbal abuse from the conductor. For many hours. I used to play in my province's honour band, so the band room is very familiar to me. Don't get me wrong; I would be content rehearsing with a band forever, but frankly watching the band room in cartoon version was kind of dull for me. The drama with auditions, the anxiety on stage, drama with who gets to play the solos (well I was the best in a section of about 5 or  played every solo) , I had experienced all of that in real life, so I guess it was interesting to watch, but story-wise not very strong for me.


Art 10/10

I believe the art is by far the strongest aspect of Euphonium. The characters are so well drawn they look shiny. The sunset through the windows, reflection from objects that cast light into the shade on a sunny day, the lights from the street lamps and cars on a street at night, the starlight mixed with the cityscape view from the mountain, the art was all mind-blowingly well done. It was so beautiful that it made my heart hurt. Strangely the most beautiful scenes were always centred around Kousaka but I'll talk about her in the characters section later. Even if you don't care for anything that was happening in the band, enjoy the art.


Sound 10/10

You probably don't need to be told this but the anime Hibike!(Sound!) Euphonium is about sound. Consequently the effort put into sound in the production was pretty amazing.

There was one moment in the anime (this might be a spoiler, but not really. I'm trying to give you adequate time to consider whether or not you will consider this a spoiler or not before you read on) where Kousaka and Kimiko climb a mountain and play a duet with the backdrop of the city's night skyline. I think this moment in the show made it worth watching for me because it was really beautiful. The duet wasn't especially complicated......it was just a really simple duet, but I found it really special and memorable.


Characters 6/10

I wasn't really a fan of most of the characters in the series. I found Kousaka to be a pretty interesting character, and after a little while Kimiko caught her interesting-ness.......if that makes any sense.

Kousaka was kind of a controversial character within her band. Because she was so good, there were people who hated her as well as loved her, but she really didn't care about any of them. She also said some.....controversial things and I'm still deciding on my understanding of her sexual preferences. I really liked how decisive and strong her personality was and I think every scene with her in it was some kind of beautiful. There were two scenes in the series that were so beautiful that they're hard to forget, and both of them involve Kousaka. The first was the scene I described above on the mountain. The second was a scene where Kousaka turns around to face Kimiko on a city street at night, and smiles for once. It was only a couple seconds long, but it was animated insanely well: the first time we see her smile, the night lights reflecting off her face, sparkling eyes, it was just amazing to watch. I feel like the creators put a little extra work when making her if you know what I mean.

Kimiko started off as kind of a indecisive person. It was pretty realistic how on the fence she was about everything, but as the story progressed she picked up on some of Kousaka's......absoluteness? I guess I was a little interested watching her become stronger.

I'm glad with what the creators did with Kousaka and Kimiko because they are so distinctly different from any other characters in anime, but other than that I didn't really see much. 


Enjoyment 8/10

Like I said before, I was a little bored by the band room scenes which take up most of the time, but seeing Kousaka be beautiful made it worth it for me. 


Overall 8/10

I feel like this was better than the average anime because of its incredible quality of production. Without showing off with action-packed fighting scenes Euphonium still tops as one of the most well animated shows I've seen. 


I wouldn't say this was a "must-watch", but those couple moments of beauty made the whole series worth it. I admit that it made me a little nostalgic and I did spontaneously run upstairs a couple times to blast a few notes on my trombone.

So is it definite that there will be a second season for this series?

Regardless of genre or theme, there has always been certain elements which accentuates a great anime from an average one and when you develop these core elements masterfully, you get a gem that outshines the other animes of its kind. Hibike! Euphonium is that gem and could easily be the best anime of Spring 2015 and maybe even best of 2015.
As it turns out, Hibike! Euphonium does in fact seem a little bland at first glance from the synopsis having being a school life story with an emphasis on music. Its been done- time and time again for example series such as K-ON!, Love Live!,and Tari Tari. What will win you over however, is the depth of the main characters, the flow of the story, and the overall animation.


Hibike! Euphonium builds a wonderful story from the ground up with a solid foundation of characters which develop over the 13 episode series along with the main plot which unfolds just as nicely. Each episode has meaning and leaves you with more than enough to keep you hooked and wanting more. By the end of the season, Hibike! Euphonium does more in 13 episodes than many anime series can do in 24. In the event that Hibike! Euphonium does not have a second season, you are still left with some closure and it doesn't make you feel like you wasted your time.


All in all, whether you are a picky anime viewer or someone pondering on what series to watch in Spring 2015, Hibike! Euphonium will not  be a disappointing choice.

The first time I saw this anime was at a convention where this was one of the showcased animes (ep 1~5) and at first it annoyed me SO much that it looked like a K-on! knockoff. The first main character looks and behaves like Yui. The second character like Mio, even black hair and one of the few to wear black footwear. The third looks, acts and even has the eyebrows like Tsumugi and the last one is way too similar to Ritsu being all two-sided and impulsive. Hibike Euphonium is probably one of the few anime series that actually somewhat portrays well the life of a band student in a nutshell. Having been a musician in that scenario before, I can somewhat relate to it. However, I would say that this anime is in no way the reality of band life. 
Story: 4. This story is an over-romanticized version of band. The main problem I had with this is that the improvement of all the students was just unreal. How can a bunch of clarinets and bass clarinets somehow tongue at 144 with just two years of experience? I can't at least,and I've been playing a wind instrument three times as long as them. To give some background, I am a bassoonist who has been in the concert band and symphony orchestra life, but now basically only in the symphony orchestra.\n
Art. 10. Who gets the keys on an oboe exactly? Kyo-ani. Amazing job; I'm honestly very impressed that they nailed it because oboe keywork is pretty complicated. \n
Sound: 5. Honestly the soundtracks were just okay. They weren't very expressive in any way, and oh man did that bassoon solo in the last episode make me cringe.\n
Characters: 6. The characters are you standard shoujo manga girls who get into petty drama etc. etc. etc. They don't really show any major character development nor any musical development. Case and point being the perpetual mindset music music and more music and I need to practice and get better so that I can get the solo etc. Being a musician, I can attest to the practicing part, but these people need to get a life. \n
Overall: 7. It was okay. I wouldn't watch this again. It's just okay, but if you're into the whole band thing I guess you'd like it.

*Very Minor Spoilers*
This one is a total 180 degree for me. At first, I wasn't really enveloped in the characters or story, as everything seemed to have a very basic premise. But after a while, the characters & story really do grow into something amazing.
The story is about a high school girl named Kumiko, who in middle school lost a big band competition that she and her friends worked hard for. It then progresses into her high school life where you see her grow as a musician and as a person, as well as her meeting new friends and watching them grow into better musicians.The entire plot is basically a huge progression to win their next competition. But they do it in a way that made me want to keep watching, even though at times it did get boring.


The art and sound are absolutely amazing. I can't say I've seen another anime that was so well done in these departments, but this one has some stunning visuals, and sound design.


And finally the characters, which at first have a pretty basic premise that you would probably see in most other anime. Thing about these characters that makes them unique is the progression I was talking about. They make the characters pretty basic in the beginning of the show, but gradually you see them all grow into amazing musicians. They demonstrate that hard work and determination is the key to making it. And honestly all the characters were pretty interesting (at least the ones that have a lot of screen time).


Overall this one, at first, was kinda boring. I did however start to gravitate toward's this anime more as it progressed. There's something about this one that just keeps having you come back and see what might happen next. Also, I would love to point out how I love the product placement we get to see (Yamaha being one of them). It's always cool to see real life products being used in an anime. And being a musician myself, I can admit that the struggles the characters were feeling, were 100% genuine. Musicians really do feel like screaming in the street when their songs don't get released on that big label.

Don’t worry guys, I’m not dead.
The Short Version:
(+)Your eyes go for a massage in God’s day spa. (The art is good)
(+)The music is much more than exceptional.
(+)Credit to the character designer.
(+)Gets a really good message across.
(-)Bit slow for my liking.
The Story (8/10): You, the person reading this, has probably been a part of a club or team at some point. One of the things that probably ran through your mind at some point when you were part of said club or team was, “What do I want from this?” Do you want to merely have fun with the team, or do you want to gofor gold? That line of thinking is more or less the reason this show exists. We start by following the MC, whose part of a concert band club, and not 5 minutes into the first episode someone says, “Weren’t we trying for nationals?” After the club gets first place but doesn’t perform well enough to advance. Then we have the high school club asked the question above, they want to go for nationals, and then they realize how hard they’re going to have to work to get there. From that point onwards we follow the MC and her friends in their journey to GIT GUD.


The Characters (8/10): Do you like various archetypes of cute girls? Then you’ll like most of the characters in this show….. Well that was a short section.


Hazuki Katou: The tuba player and the eccentric one of the core characters.


Sapphire “Midori” Kawashime: Contrabass and the curly headed one.


Reina Kousaka: Trumpet and the hardest working.


Kumiko Oumae: Euphonium of the title and the main character.


Again as I said above if you like cute girls this show has got you covered. However there is another character that is pretty monumental throughout the show and that’s the club adviser Noburo Taki who basically adopts the outlook of, “Sit down and shut up you little shits you told me you wanted to win nationals, I’m going to make that happen and it’s sink or swim for all of you at any point.”


The Art & Sound (9/10) & (8/10): The art is really good, visual quality is awesome, but the detail of most things that aren’t the instruments is kinda lacking, and all of the characters look like they’ve dumped their faces into a basin of vegetable oil.


This being an anime about a concert club, I expected the sound to be really good. Except it turned out to be really really good. Even when the band first gets together to play an ensemble you can tell the difference between then and the next time they play, they genuinely improve over the course of the show and that’s a very positive point for the show.


What do you think of this anime?


Do you want a detox from all of the full paced anime out there? Then do I have the anime for you.


Would you recommend this anime?


Yes. Go watch it.


Goodbye my brethren,  see you in the next one.

KyoAni does it again(after small mishaps)! Let's get right down to it!
=== STORY: 7 = 
While it's not anything out of the ordinary for a slice of life anime - especially with such a narrow focus - the pacing was perfect. The amount of side dishes we had on top of the main dish - school band practice - was just right. It was obvious what was the story about and what was a "bonus". No sidesteps - pure focus on the main story.
In short - an ok story that you'd expect from Slice of Life told in an ok way.
=== ART: 7 ===
The animation,the characters, the hair physics, the backgrounds, the shading, the play on light... It was all executed perfectly. The amount of details from first few episodes began to diminish over time until we hit the rock bottom at the finale; don't get me wrong it was still well and above 90% of stuff I've watched so far - the first 6 episodes just spoiled me a little too much. The amount of effects felt a little over the top at some moments - 2 scenes to be exact - but other than that it was all well done.


It's beautiful, it's well done, it felt crisp and alive. It was nowhere close to Makoto Shinkai's photorealism, though. It would be an 8 if the amount of details was the same throughout all 13 episodes.


=== SOUND: 8 ===

It was really good. Instrumental flukes were captured perfectly, voice acting was pretty much perfect, the ambient in most scenes was ok, but the music... Music felt flat for some reason - I've even rewatched the musical parts on studio-grade equipment and it still felt flat. I'd give 7 for sound but the flukes in the practice scenes(sound acting?) and voice acting raised the grade to 8.


=== CHARACTER: 8 ===

Characters were good. They were not flat, their struggles and emotions were shown. Their designs made it easy to distinguish them from each other - every single one of the ~70 members of the band had some features unique to them - despite the fact that most did not even matter when it came to the story of the main heroine(And that bunch was not the only group portrayed!). Their behavior felt so natural and each had so little screen time that it's hard to even talk about archetypes and such - 13 episodes we were given felt like a glimpse on a small part of the cast's lives. 


8 for the huge quantity of differing characters, talking about quality of such small samples feels like a waste of time. The only character we got to see fully was the Main Heroine. BUT this is not psychological drama and we don't need to know the full story of every single band member so it's all good.


=== ENJOYMENT: 10 ===

There's not much I can say about this one - I really enjoyed this series and I don't regret even a single minute spent(rarely happens!). I did not even yawn once! Watched with my eyes glued to the screen, and my heart was pounding by the finale. 10/10!


===== OVERALL: 9 =====

It does what it had to do great - despite the story being simple, despite the small mishaps, despite this and that - I really enjoyed the anime and that's all that really matters. It's eyecandy and a balm for the soul - especially after that monstrosity that is Owari no Seraph ;_; WATCH THIS IF YOU DO NOT LIKE OVERLY COMPLICATED STORIES AND LIKE YOUR THINGS HAPPY!

I have a complicated relationship with Kyoto Animation. Their art and the quality of animation are very good, but, unfortunately, most of their shows or TV adaptations start to go downhill after a few episodes and I only ended up enjoying Suzumiya Haruhi no Yuutsu and Nichijou, K-On! was passable and I failed to sit through one of their biggest hits, Free!. Perhaps, it is a bit unfair, but let's be honest, if I cannot bring myself to watch at least one episode, why should I force myself to continue watching something that failed to keep me interested for at least 20 minutes?
I decided towatch this because I wanted something short and slice-of-life-esque and because I tried to watch it once but got distracted. And I have to admit, I was pleasantly surprised.


So, let's talk about this show's strong and weak sides, shall we?


Pros.

Animation and art are, without a doubt, beautiful and colorful. The story is more complicated than it seems to be at the beginning and its main idea is a breath of fresh air in comparison to shows about bands in the Pop Music genre and/or idols with music and songs that are easy to forget. An orchestra club is a very unusual theme for an anime about ordinary school days, and seeing how determined and enthusiastic the characters are makes you feel kind of proud. They set a goal and they work hard to achieve it, overcoming obstacles and hardships in the process. Characters are flawed, they have their issues and secrets, they make mistakes yet their determination and love for music are inspiring. If I may compare it to K-On, Hibike! Euphonium is more music-centered, I enjoy this aspect very much because I am not quite fond of watching characters beating about the bush while eating sweets and drinking tea all the time. This show is about working and working real hard in order to make it to the contest and win. I think it's nice that a slice of life story has a clear plot instead of each episode being a bunch of unrelated stories. Not that I dislike this type of storytelling, but it's nice to see something different for a change.


Cons.

Unfortunately, it can be hard to become attached to different characters or genuinely care for them. I was proud of the club as a whole, but, unfortunately, failed to root for a particular character. They're not bad, but, despite their good qualities and flaws, they may seem a bit bland sometimes. They just... exist. It took me a while to find a character I could consider my favorite and I treated them all equally without any emotions or feelings towards them. Maybe this equality is not bad, but I personally like characters I can worry cheer for and worry about (for example, I care a lot for Azusa from K-On!). Eventually, I started liking Natsuki Nakagawa, she is still my favorite. I suppose they could be a bit brighter because no one really stands out and I still have a hard time remembering their names. Also, the characters work hard. Very hard. And it's admirable. As a result, make sure you're ready to listen to the same tunes over and over again to the point where they start getting on your nerves a bit. This is how it's supposed to be, given that they cannot just hop from one song to another.


Overall, this series is enjoyable, and if you think that the flaws I have mentioned above can be overlooked (who knows, maybe you're going to feel differently about characters and the story), go ahead and watch it and I believe you won't be disappointed. It's nothing revolutionary, but it's a nice experience.

Brief synopsis
After a traumatic experience in middle school, Kimiko is reluctant to have anything to do with music and upon entering high school seeks a fresh start. Nevertheless, she finds herself inexplicably pulled back into the world of music. With new friends in tow, Kimiko faces many trials to compete with the concert band to reach the Nationals.
Story
Whilst the premise of the show is simple enough (and by no means original) that does not stop it from being enjoyable. Something about striving towards a goal that you are incredibly passionate about with all of the energy and resilience that youth affords you, with equally passionatefriends, overcoming trials along the way and growing all the more stronger for it, resonates deep within me. Shows like this never fail to move me. And, indeed, there was more than one occasion when I was moved while watching this show. This show’s themes – a passion for music, friendship, and hard work – combined with its art and beautiful music to make me feel this way.


I was glad that the theme of romantic love took a back seat to the above themes, as that allowed the viewer to focus on the beauty and earnestness of the friendship between the main characters.

My only criticism would be with the pacing of the show. After its completion, the band’s journey towards the Nationals had still only just begun. Whilst I understand that there is a second season, I would have liked to have seen this journey progress much further than it did.


Art

Stunning animation and art, as per the norm for KyoAni.


Music

Pleasant. My only criticism would be that there wasn’t more of it. The concert band only played a handful of pieces throughout the entire show and these were played over and over again as they practiced them. I don’t know how the show could have overcome this issue, however, as practice is a necessary part of playing in a band…


Characters  

This show had a strong cast of both main and supporting characters. Each character was interesting and had their own unique set of characteristics and quirks. I particularly liked the relationship between Kimiko and Reina. It was a touch obsessive and both put the other on a pedestal, but I think that this reflects the intensity that is often characteristic of the friendships that you make as a young adult, friendships where you desperately seek the validation of another (seemingly cooler) person as you wrestle with who you are as a person.


Overall enjoyment

Hibike! Euphonium had numerous strengths, including its music, its story – with its themes of friendship, hard work, and a passion for music – its art, and its likeable, believable characters. In fact, I struggle to think of any major flaws, therefore, I’d say that I enjoyed it immensely and would definitely recommend watching it.

Personal Rating- 9
Actual- ~9.5
Sound! Euphonium was fantasic for myself because I could relate to it so much as a band person (#Percussion). Every part of the anime was executed smoothly and was well done. There weren't many mistakes in my opinion and the ones that were present were not Major and were minor.
STORY- 9.5
The story was enthralling because I myself am part of a wind band and I'm extremely passionate as a member. The show really appealed to me using a story of a trashy-band that transforms into a top-tier band was a great move instead of just focusing on 1 player/instrument (As the titlesuggests). 


Execution-9

Execution wise it was great. The story was cleanly executed without large gaping plot holes and the transitions between events were also smooth. I wouldn't say it was completely perfect though, but the mistakes are not important in affecting the main storyline.


Originality- 10

There have been many shows based on music, but Sound! Euphonium was completely unique using a wind band as a music focus versus the many piano, violin, and pop band focus. There haven't been any shows (That I've heard of) that are based on a wind band which makes this 100% original.


QUALITY- 9.66

The overall quality was phenomenal in both the animation studio and the sound department. Both combined with the characters to create a beautiful anime overall.


Animation-10

The animation was extravagant. The lighting and shading was marvelous and created many scenes that would make create background images. There was also proper usage of special effects that emphasized a character or a scene. The instruments were as well animated realistically and beautifully.


Sound- 10

The sounds of the instruments were completely real and the players that recorded them were seasoned musicians. I could clearly hear the articulation and double-tongue in quick-succesive notes and the vibrato in lyrical phrases (for example Reina's solo). The OST and musical selections were also outstanding. Crescent Moon Dance was a beautiful piece that I would like to perform now and the background songs suited the scences. The OP and ED were also catchy and I never skipped them.


Characters- 9 

The characters were not too cliche or predictable. The characters were well developed and realistic. One could describe each character fully without having any trouble. Some characters were left undeveloped or just not fully developed, for example Aoi. She seemed fairly important but when she quit, the explanation was there but was not explained clearly. Overall the characters were great.


Enjoyment- 9 

As a band geek and music enthusiast, there's no way that I couldn't enjoy this show. It portrayed band pretty accurately but I will rant on a minor detail-

/* Rant start

I honestly still nitpick those marching keyboards, specifically the xylo -like nobody does that because it's extremely heavy and difficult to play without looking down, and to add on top of that it was a fragile-looking girl marching it. To add the cherry and cream, there's a thing called "Front Ensemble" for all the keyboards, in a street parade there would not be a front ensemble or keyboards (excluding glockenspiel at a rare chance.)

*\ Rant end

Otherwise from that, I enjoyed this show completely.

this is a spoiler-free review, so with that in mind, feel at ease to proceed without fear of stumbling upon, well, spoilers. i’ve kept my sentiments brief, and if you don’t like mile-long or professional reviews, you’re at the right place boi!1!
when i started watching it, i honestly didn’t expect that i'd be interested enough to keep on watching, much less enjoy it. first of all, i’m not too big on slice-of-life genres. sure, there are exceptions like hyouka (which just so happens to be one of my favourite animes), but on the whole, they’re really just not my thing. i find it hard tofinish those kinds of anime, and the reason for it can be simply boiled down to one sentence: i’m more of a guts, blood, and gore type of person.


getting back to what i think of this show …


i loved it, i really did --not going to lie, the kumikoxreina scenes helped seal the deal. the animation was unsurprisingly spectacular, and the storyline simple but so .. honest (sorry, i can’t come up with something better, im tired AF) in its execution. there’s something about the characters and their interactions that really drew me in, and, the slight moe factor aside, the show has a genuine sense of realism to it that you’d be hard-pressed to find elsewhere. i’m still in awe of how fleshed-out and nuanced the characters were, and if you’d like a show with three-dimensional beings with distinct personalities, you’ve found it. thinking about it, kyoani could have added an exciting spin to the whole premise, but i’m actually glad for its simplicity.


the end

This anime really exceeded my expectations. It was one of the best proposals for an anime but as they say: You can not judge a book by its cover.
At first I thought the middle unmotivated protagonist (as always have that disagreement in the past), was solved very easily because Reina did not hurt, she just decided to improve and improve to be '' special ''.
The character development in general is very good, the anime revolves not only around Kumiko, shows how is the current situation of the characters, the house of them has a frustration something that bothers them, I think it's very good becauseI want to know what you want they feel, their opinions and that's what they did not let any of it go, that feeling of them nervous and anxious I could feel real.\n
The music is spectacular, they may have started bad but were overcoming every obstacle, I think there at that club again and many tried to give up (as well as Aoi-chan) but I think the feeling of reaching the National was stronger, some did not like others, others needed more training, but never gave up their goals !! And it had a great help from the teacher, he was very rude but it all had a purpose, was not an act in vain. And I can say that much worth the rudeness of it.\n
Kumiko and Reina, I do not really like them both together as a couple, but I see them as best friends, one helping the other in difficult times (although I suspect the only Reina like the Taki same sensei). But their relationship has improved a lot since the first episode there was forming a loop (perhaps friendship or love) music formed the music joined the two, it is very beautiful!\n
In terms of animation KyoAni left me more impressed than in other animes it.\n
My favorite scenes are the night, are incredibly beautiful, I can not say much more it seems they highlight the light and the effect is very good, love the desing of the characters as well. And especially the soundtrack!\n
Well, from what I saw it was resolved by the friendship and music and they managed to get where they wanted to, overall everyone had a good development and ended better than I expected, really this was an anime very, very beautiful and I am very anxious to the second season to be coming!\n
