Hibike has to be one of my favourites from Kyoani besides K-on!, Kyoukai no kanata and Free! This show man, it took me on a huge emotional rollercoaster. The character development was outstanding, not even mentioning how beautifull the art and music were. I'm in love with this series and i enjoyed every second of it. I highly reccomend watching it. The story ending was very satisfying and nice. 
I loved this series mainly because of the relationship growing between Kumiko and Reina, this might also be the main reason why i was watching this show in the first place, but that aside. 
Overall, goodstory, good character development, Beautifull BGM and art. As to be expected from Kyoani.\n\n

A show about a high-school band from Kyoto Animation…hmm, where have I heard this before?  In all seriousness though, Hibike! Euphonium has become one of my favorite TV shows of all time.  It’s the rare show where I have to pause multiple times an episode because I’m so overwhelmed by how good it is, but that’s the experience I had watching Euphonium.  
Let me start with an understatement: Euphonium’s animation is gorgeous.  KyoAni outdid itself with this series, particularly with respect to the instrument details (though admittedly, I was never a band geek in high school or college so if thedetails were wrong I wouldn’t be the wiser).  Certain scenes even rival Hyouka, another KyoAni title that I personally consider to have the best art direction of any show I’ve watched.  And like in Hyouka, Euphonium’s high school setting exhibits an incredible degree of verisimilitude; it not only looks like a real high school, the teachers and students behave like real teachers and students.  As someone who has come to expect depictions of high school in anime to be rather “fantastical”—ranging from the magical intrusions in Clannad to the ridiculous insanity of Kill la Kill—Euphonium was a refreshing change of pace.


I have a deep appreciation for realism in storytelling; this is particularly true with respect to animated works, given that they are inherently one step removed from reality and thus constantly have to work harder to achieve an effect comparable to a live-action production.  That being said, everything in Euphonium feels real and true-to-life; for me, it is one of the show's biggest draws, setting it apart (and above) all other high-school-set shows I've seen up to this point.  Euphonium absolutely nails what being in high school is like: the relationships, the rivalries, the anxieties, and the disappointments.  The show's depiction of band politics is especially on the nose, showcasing the practical difficulties in uniting 50+ high-school students, each with their own egos and motivations, behind a common goal.  


The story itself is rather straightforward—a dysfunctional high-school band rallies behind their up-and-coming superstar music teacher to compete for a trip to the national tournament—but what makes the show truly great are the characters and their interactions with each other.  The cast is extremely likeable, and despite having a relatively large ensemble the show does a good job juggling the screentime each character receives so that even minor characters get a chance to shine.  Moreover, the relationship that emerges between Kumiko (the awkward protagonist who plays the euphonium) and Reina (her passionate foil who plays the trumpet) is one of my favorites in all of anime.  Special mention also goes to Natsuki, a second-year euphonium player who starts out as an indifferent slacker but, over the course of the series, makes strides to become Kumiko’s friend and role model.


Hibike! Euphonium has edged The Disappearance of Haruhi Suzumiya as my favorite work from KyoAni, and like Disappearance it gets an easy 10/10.  I can’t recommend this show enough; it was a joy to watch from beginning to end, and I eagerly await the debut of its Season 2 to see how the story continues.

Might include minor spoilers, I'm not sure what kind of spoilers are worth being called spoilers for slice of life anime.
Story (7/10)
The story revolve around a lot of pratice sessions, and the club's internal problems regarding the upcoming competition. Afterall, this anime is about improving their music play.
Rant: The bad score doesn't signify a bad plot or a lack of it, instead I think this anime had a lot (maybe even too much) of the plot. Having a 'Music' genre stamped to it, I reallt hoped I could have even more awesome musics being played rather than the story. But IMO this anime is focusingmore on the story and internal problems in the ensemble team rather than actually playing music. Well maybe I'm wrong, but in total there are only 2 piece of music being played (actually make that 1 because the 1st one is not being played fully, only lasting for a few minutes). But they also have practice session which include some section of the music sometimes. Well, compared to Shigatsu wa Kimi no Uso, that have like 6 (I forgot the count) pieces of music being played fully, it lost in comparison. Maybe it was the plot pacing's fault, if the pacing was stepped up a bit, we might even cover more competitions and and more awesome orchestral music's play. While I'm on it, the agata festival episode really felt out of the place.


But that might be just me, for people that doesn't mind the pacing, it might be perfect for them.



Art (10/10)

Great art, really awesome and good looking, it's almost perfect. What really amazes me was how it had depth of perception in every scenes possible, which we rarely even see in anime. The only downfall for me was the character design, don't get me wrong, I really like the character designs, a lot, what I don't like was the everpresent weird blush on the girls, feels off-putting sometimes.



Sound (10/10)

Despite what I said about lacking any actual full musics playing, the quality of the musics was great, it also depicts the training sessions beautifully. I just need more. Well, maybe hiring a wind ensemble to record the sounds was pricy for the anime productions.



Character (10/10)

I think the characters are great. I really love their personalities. They're not your standard moe chara. Despite how it looks real cute (as expected kyoani) a lot of them had some difficult personalities. Like how Kumiko looked like she had a generic good-girl personality, but constantly throwing her retorts of the things happening around her. And how Asuka have this I-don't-give-a-shit aura around her despite how friendly she looks.



Enjoyment (9/10)

If you liked slow pacing anime then this might be good for you.



Yuri (10/10)

Yuri is one of the aspect that made this anime great (for me at least). I loved how its treading between heartwarming-comedic-girl-friendship yuri and sakura trick level yuri.



Overall (9/10)

tl;dr Expect moe with a lot of wind ensemble team musical practice.
